[]Author: Isabella Dicaprio;
Rating: 5
When: a week ago
I suggest looking at this city not only as a work of art and opulence, but also historic and controversial. They have done a great job at preserving these fantastic displays of art. The entrance is free but the wait may be long. I highly recommend to go up the dome of the basilica. It's worth the money and effort. When you walk on the roof, you'll see a complete different view as of being down on the plaza.

Author: Thomas Sallermann;
Rating: 4
When: 7 months ago
This is the most important place in Roman Catholicism. The building in itself is quite impressive. You can discover lots of beautiful art. Fortunately not all the moneyğŸ’¶ made by the church is given to the poor. It seems that comparatively few people come here to pray (I discovered some nuns in a small chapel doing this). Please wear the maskğŸ˜·. Protect the Vatican.

Author: Vedat OdacÄ±;
Rating: 4
When: 3 months ago
We can call St. Peter's Basilica as the most important Catholic House of Worship in the world. Just as the Kaaba is important for Muslims, St. Peter's Basilica is of similar importance to Christians. The only difference is that in addition to its religious importance, this place is also interesting in terms of art and tourism. The basilica, one of the 12 apostles of Christ and built on the tomb of St. Peter's (or at least the tomb of the person thought to be St. It is also one of the most important stops of travel. Being the largest church in the world in terms of its area of â€‹â€‹coverage, St. In addition to being a religious building, Peterâ€™s Basilica is an exquisite example of Renaissance architecture and perhaps the most expensive artworks in the world. Located in the heart of the Vatican, in St. Peter's Square (St. Peter's Square or St. Peter's Square), St. Peter's Basilica is an important and striking structure with its interior, exterior, underground part, in short, with every centimeter.

Author: Al Dhalla;
Rating: 5
When: 3 months ago
It was an incredible experience. We joined a tour group. They picked us up from the hotel and they assisted us through the security and had preferred seating for us. We attended a mass. We had a great view of the Pope as he entered the area and took some great photos. After the mass, we walked around, visited the gift shop, got some lunch and went back to our hotel. Overall great visit and highly recommended. Thank you.

Author: Muthu;
Rating: 5
When: a week ago
A visit to Rome will not be complete without a visit to Vatican City, and St. Peterâ€™s Basilica is the most important place to visit in Vatican. It is the largest church in the world. There is a stunning view of Rome and St. Peterâ€™s Square from the Dome of St. Peterâ€™s Basilica. The two semi circular colonnades by Bernini with the Egyptian Obelisk in the middle look impressive from the dome. But there is no elevator to this part of the structure.

[]Author: Claudia Andrea C;
Rating: 5
When: 9 months ago
A must! I would highly recommend to assign half a day to the museums, in order to see everything inside. It is really big and it could take a while to finish it. Take comfy shoes because you will walk a lot. Also don't forget your water.

Author: James Blassingame;
Rating: 5
When: 8 months ago
If you find yourself in Rome, do what the Romans do.........check out The Vatican!!! The earlier in the day that you can get there the better off you will be. This place gets PACKED!!! Not really an issue right now, but when school is in session the school groups swamp the place, and that's not even mentioning regular tourist. The setting is immaculate, absolutely beautiful. One thing that I noticed, there was a legit military/law enforcement presence at the Vatican. If someone is going there with the intention of breaking bad, I pray for their soul. The armed guards aren't playing, and looked legit as any military operation I can think of. The Sistine Chapel is a sight to behold, worth the churning herd of people to see it in person. Don't pull your cameras out, they don't take too kindly to that either. This isn't from personal experience, but I didn't see some people who encountered issues.

Author: Angelos Odyseakis;
Rating: 5
When: 8 months ago
Amazing experience, but very crowded.

Author: Mrs Mrs;
Rating: 5
When: 7 months ago
A fantastic museum that is like a time capsule. There are displays that go back as far as Constantine, all the way up to the present day. We were lucky enough to have come on an evening tour and the museum was not crowded. Our tour guide was able to give fantastic insight into the pieces of art and relics on display. The artwork on the ceiling is amazing, it looks like 3D plaster but it's not it's actually all hand painted!

Author: akshay timmalapur;
Rating: 5
When: 7 months ago
One of the best kept museums. Vatican is smallest country but it never stopped them from building one of the world's largest museum. Buy tickets online and avoid large crowds at the queues

[]Author: David Herbst;
Rating: 3
When: 5 months ago
I can appreciate the history behind it but I fail to understand why the ceiling of this place seems to be one of the highlights of Rome. If you can, be sure to do the entire tour of the Vatican Museum. Along your way you will see dozens of long hallways with tall ceilings, all of which are painted with beautiful art. Don't rush to see it, rather enjoy all the other beautiful art Rome shows you just by walking anywhere.

Author: Daniela Romero;
Rating: 5
When: 2 weeks ago
Itâ€™s just stunning. Somehow we got there but the journey was a labyrinth. We did not follow the signs, just moved by instincts and it seems it was designed to be the last part of the tour. Obviously we were not allowed to take pictures and it was crowded, so we just enjoyed the view for some minutes. You can also take sit to stay a little longer there.

Author: Dmitriy Mitin;
Rating: 5
When: 9 months ago
This place has already more than 32k reviews, so I don't think I could add something new. I was blessed to visit this place during the pandemic - it was so calm and peaceful without tourists. As a short remark - if you take an audio guide, the content will be different for different languages. The most complete is Italian and English.

Author: heath;
Rating: 4
When: a month ago
The most magnificent architecture in Rome. The paintings were fascinating. The whole experience was engaging. My only complaint is that some in my family are claustrophobic, and they were letting way too many people into a room at a time. They packed some rooms full so that there was virtually no room. Other than that, it was an amazing experience.

Author: Karen Blanco;
Rating: 5
When: 8 months ago
A must see. So much art and so much more. Tons of stolen relics from other cultures are on display here. This is the Louvre of Italy, if you like seeing everything you may need a full day or two

Rating: 3

Author: Call Me M.;
Rating: 5
When: 6 months ago
Probably one of the most beautiful spots in Rome. It's a quiet, relaxing place that is filled with exquisite art from all over the world. foreign trees and parrots (that were gifts to the Popes) also make up most of the fauna and flora. interestingly there are also some greek gods portraied in there! I highly suggest you take time to visit the Vatican Gardens, its worth every penny and second spent in there!

Author: Dan (DV);
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
The bus tour was great, especially for the end of December when it can get cold. The bus had a plastic cover so you don't face any wind. There was practically no queue. You're allowed in with ~45 minutes before the time on the ticket and in no time you're past the scanners. There are separate counters from where you can get the tickets insinde the building (almost no line). When the tour is done, you can visit the rest of the museum; no other waiting involved.

Author: Levent Parman;
Rating: 4
When: 10 months ago
JazzÂ is aÂ music genreÂ that originated in theÂ African-AmericanÂ communities ofÂ New Orleans, United States, in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, with its roots inÂ bluesÂ andÂ ragtime.Â Since the 1920sÂ Jazz Age, it has been recognized as a major form of musical expression inÂ traditionalÂ andÂ popular music, linked by the common bonds of African-American andÂ European-AmericanÂ musical parentage.Â Jazz is characterized byÂ swingÂ andÂ blue notes,Â call and response vocals,Â polyrhythmsÂ andÂ improvisation. Jazz has roots inÂ West African cultural and musical expression, and inÂ African-American music traditions.As jazz spread around the world, it drew on national, regional, and local musical cultures, which gave rise to different styles.Â New Orleans jazzÂ began in the early 1910s, combining earlier brass-band marches, FrenchÂ quadrilles,Â biguine, ragtime andÂ bluesÂ with collectiveÂ polyphonicÂ improvisation. In the 1930s, heavily arranged dance-orientedÂ swingÂ big bands,Â Kansas City jazz, a hard-swinging, bluesy, improvisational style andÂ Gypsy jazzÂ (a style that emphasizedÂ musetteÂ waltzes) were the prominent styles.Â BebopÂ emerged in the 1940s, shifting jazz from danceable popular music toward a more challenging "musician's music" which was played at faster tempos and used more chord-based improvisation.Â Cool jazzÂ developed near the end of the 1940s, introducing calmer, smoother sounds and long, linear melodic lines. The mid-1950s saw the emergence ofÂ hard bop, which introduced influences fromÂ rhythm and blues,Â gospel, and blues, especially in the saxophone and piano playing.Â Modal jazzÂ developed in the late 1950s, using theÂ mode, or musical scale, as the basis of musical structure and improvisation, as didÂ free jazz, which explored playing without regular meter, beat and formal structures.Â Jazz-rock fusionÂ appeared in the late 1960s and early 1970s, combining jazz improvisation withÂ rock music's rhythms, electric instruments, and highly amplified stage sound. In the early 1980s, a commercial form of jazz fusion calledÂ smooth jazzÂ became successful, garnering significant radio airplay. Other styles and genres abound in the 2000s, such asÂ LatinÂ andÂ Afro-Cuban jazz.
